explanation:
For determining whether OS_TaskDelete_Impl calls itself (directly or indirectly) the analyzer needs the definitions/implementations of all routines, macros, and types that OS_TaskDelete_Impl invokes or uses so any call paths back to OS_TaskDelete_Impl (or OS_TaskDelete) can be discovered:

- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken: Direct callee (via the object-table access); need its body to ensure it does not call OS_TaskDelete_Impl or OS_TaskDelete.
- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET (macro or inline accessor): The macro/inline expansion performs the token->index lookup; its expansion may call other functions — include it to inspect any hidden calls that could form a cycle.
- OS_impl_task_table (object): The object/table accessor may reference helper functions; include to inspect related accessors or hooks.
- OS_impl_task_internal_record_t (struct/type): Required to confirm the type of impl->id (and whether accessing it triggers function calls, e.g., accessor functions) and to ensure no function-call side effects occur when reading fields.
- pthread_cancel: Called directly; include its declaration/semantics to confirm it does not invoke user callbacks that could call back into OS_TaskDelete_Impl (normally it will not, but include for completeness).
- pthread_join: Called directly; include to ensure no implementation-specific hooks invoke application functions that could recurse.
- OS_ObjectIdFromToken: Called (indirectly via OS_ObjectIdToInteger call arguments); include to verify it does not call back into OS_TaskDelete_Impl/OS_TaskDelete.
- OS_ObjectIdToInteger: Called to format debug output; include to verify it does not call back into the target functions.
- strerror: Library call used for debug; include to ensure no unexpected callbacks.
- OS_DEBUG (macro/function): Used for logging; its implementation may call other OS services — include it to check whether logging could call OS_TaskDelete_Impl or its callers.
- OS_SUCCESS (macro/enum): Return value; include to confirm it is a simple constant (no functions) and to complete the function's behavior model.

Including these symbols (implementations or expansions) lets the next agent trace all direct callees and any functions they invoke, so it can determine if any path leads back to OS_TaskDelete_Impl or OS_TaskDelete, which would constitute direct or indirect recursion under the MISRA rule.
